data.title: Pranjal Chalise - Peer Career Advisor at Amherst College | The Org
data.snippet:
# Pranjal Chalise

### Peer Career Advisor

Pranjal Chalise is a Software Engineer at Microsoft since June 2025, specializing in CoreAI. Concurrently, Pranjal serves as a Peer Career Advisor and a Peer Tutor in both the Math and Computer Science Departments at Amherst College, providing support for students in academic and professional development. Pranjal's prior experience includes working as an AI/ML Fellow and Software Engineer at Microsoft in 2024, and holding various roles at Amherst College such as Math & Stats Student Steering Committee Fellow and IT Specialist. Additionally, Pranjal contributed as a Research Assistant and Research Scholar at Incubate Nepal and is pursuing a Bachelor of Arts in Computer Science and Mathematics at Amherst College, expected to graduate in May 2026. [...] Log inSign up

data.title: Pranjal Chalise: An Enthusiastic Technopreneur! - Glocal Teen Hero
data.snippet:
Besides this; He is also working in BloomED (Bloom School Nepal), a non-profit educational and academic resource platform. He has been working as a content creation intern and contributed in drafting the educational resources that will be distributed to many students in disadvantage.

In the future, he envisions himself honing and upgrading talents, investing heavily in intensive training to obtain more advanced technology skills so that he may best serve the community.

##### Pranjal Chalise has been selected as a ‚ÄúGlocal‚Äôs 20under20 of 2021 Batch‚Äù as an early change-maker throughout the nation. Glocal‚Äôs 20 under 20 is an umbrella title for 20 early change-makers, who are teenagers from diverse fields, stepping out to create an impact in the society.

###### Next Post [...] Pranjal has aided the Blind Community by inventing Drishti Nepal, which helps the blind community in currency bills recognition and cash transactions. By creating Kisan Nepal, a mobile application that offers agricultural news and information from reliable sources and keeps farmers informed and alert, he has helped to alleviate agricultural and farmer limitations. 

Currently, He is working as an incubator and app developer at Incubate Nepal. He is recognized as one of the brightest high school students (One of 20 selected students from all disciplines and one of 10 for Computer Science) from all over Nepal to work on open-end research projects under the mentorship of MIT and Harvard graduates. [...] Apart from that; He is the founder & Project Mentor of Students Research Council Nepal (SRCN), (an organization that provides the platform of research and project-based education to high-school enthusiasts and provides paper-writing and app development training). He finished the initial round of research and launched Gyan-E, Nepal‚Äôs first-ever discussion forum. They have guided 7 brilliant high schoolers under his mentorship. In the International Journal, SRCN has successfully published 4 research papers.

As a Computer Science Mentor, he taught coding and mobile app development to high school students. His work has been recognized by the Nepal Academy of Science and Technology for their efforts to introduce the concept of research and instill it in young students.

data.title: Student Staff - Loeb Center for Career Exploration and Planning
data.snippet:
At Amherst, I‚Äôm involved in research with the Chemistry department on energy transfer using quantum dots for different applications. Since freshman year, I‚Äôve been involved in research with the Spanish/LLAS department on community filmmaking in Latin America. On campus I‚Äôm a member of La Causa, La Fe, and Questbridge. Last semester, I attended the American Educational Research Association‚Äôs international conference in Philadelphia. This summer I had the pleasure of doing a research internship at UPenn in the Mechanical/Chemical Engineering department.

In my free time, I enjoy spending time in nature, baking, watching Netflix, and getting boba with friends. [...] Esther Jagwer is a senior at Amherst College majoring in Neuroscience on the pre-med track. Born in Botswana to Ugandan immigrants, she is committed to making an impact in every community she is part of. Her academic and research interests lie at the intersection of neuroscience, reproductive justice, and global health, with a focus on HIV/AIDS, maternal health, and health systems in Sub-Saharan Africa. She is currently conducting HIV-focused global health research in Botswana as an intern at the Children‚Äôs Hospital of Philadelphia and is also a research intern with the Black Feminist Reproductive Justice Equity & HIV/AIDS Activism (BREHA) lab on campus. Outside of academics, Esther enjoys serving on the Culinary Club e-board, planning activities, and sharing meals with peers. As a [...] I am a member of the Amherst Women‚Äôs Cross Country and Track and Field team. When I am not running, you can often find me in the music building or the science center, as I am a member of the Glee Club and Concert Choir while co-leading the Mammoth MakerLab Club. For the past two years, I have been a member of the Education Professions group and enjoy having meaningful discussions and workshops with my peers. In my free time, I also love hiking, biking, reading, and spending time with my family and friends.

data.title: 5 Most Commonly Asked Questions I Get About Resumes as a Peer ...
data.snippet:
Answer: You should list your GPA if it is 3.5 or higher, or if the employer asks for it in the application. If your GPA is lower, that is completely fine. You can focus on highlighting relevant coursework, projects, or other academic accomplishments instead.

### 4. ‚ÄúHow many experiences should I include?‚Äù

Answer: A good goal is to include three to five experiences that feel most relevant to the roles you are applying for. These do not have to be jobs. Research, leadership roles, class projects, and volunteer experiences can all be great to include if they show your skills and strengths. It is always better to have a few strong experiences than a long list with little detail.

### 5. ‚ÄúHow can my resume stand out?‚Äù [...] ### 2. ‚ÄúHow do I write a strong experience section?‚Äù

Answer: Keep your bullet points simple and clear. Start each one with an action verb, focus on what you achieved, and highlight the skills you used. Aim for one to three bullets for each experience. A helpful way to write these is to think: What did I do, how did I do it, and why did it matter?

You can also use the STAR Method, which stands for Situation, Task, Action, and Result. It is a great tool for explaining your impact in a structured way. You can learn more about the STAR Method in the Loeb Center‚Äôs How-To Guides.

### 3. ‚ÄúShould I include my GPA and what counts as a good one?‚Äù [...] Homepage

# 5 Most Commonly Asked Questions I Get About Resumes as a Peer Career Advisor

### 1. ‚ÄúWhat do employers actually look for in a resume?‚Äù

Answer: Employers want to quickly understand who you are, what you have done, and why you might be a good fit. They look for clarity, relevant experience, real impact, and clean formatting. The strongest resumes show results, like ‚Äúincreased engagement by 20%,‚Äù instead of just listing tasks.

It also really helps to read the job description closely and tailor your resume to match what the employer is asking for. Showing that you understand what they need makes a big difference.

### 2. ‚ÄúHow do I write a strong experience section?‚Äù
